A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: This episode in the Star Wars series had me thinking about its motifs and meaning long after the movie ended. While the Force Awakens was an enjoyable throw-back that plucked at the heartstrings of a sentimental audience\, it was all largely expected - a reiteration of what we've seen (and loved) before. After the Force Awakens\, my most burning question was\, \"who are Rey's parents?\" After Last Jedi\, my lingering questions are much deeper. I love the idea that the Force exists beyond the notions of Jedi and Sith\, that it doesn't belong to a religion or bloodline. I'm excited that the story will evolve\, while not entirely abandoning the history and basic principles of this Universe. I love the purposeful way in which the filmmakers set up familiar scenes\, and then pivoted away from the expected result. I didn't leave the theater with the same child-like excitement I experienced when I saw the Force Awakens\, and maybe that's why folks are disappointed\, but I think this was an enjoyable\, thoughtful - and probably necessary - next step in the story. I'm excited to see where it all goes from here and not just because I want to know who someone's parents are.
